The investigation continues into why the driver of a Tesla crashed into a light rail parking lot in Folsom on Thursday, Jan. 22, an accident that tragically killed a pedestrian.
The crash happened just before 3 p.m. in the area of Folsom Blvd. and Iron Point Road at the Iron Point Light Rail station.
According to Folsom Police Commander Andrew Bates, the most current information is the vehicle veered off the roadway for unknown reasons, crashed into the light rail parking lot and struck a pedestrian and parked car before coming to rest on the light rail tracks.
The pedestrian was pronounced dead at the scene, according to Folsom PD Lt. Lou Wright, and the driver of the Tesla sustained injuries and was taken to a hospital.
SacRT reported the vehicle struck the ramp at the station and flipped over onto the tracks. The incident blocked the tracks between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom stations, which prompted a temporary halt of service.
Investigators were on scene trying to piece together what caused the crash and SacRT crews inspected the tracks to ensure there was no damage before service was resumed in the evening.
The crash created quite a spectacle, with various media outlets on scene taking pictures and video and onlookers also taking pictures.

Ongoing investigation into why Tesla crashed into Folsom light rail lot, killing pedestrian

The investigation continues into why the driver of a Tesla crashed into a light rail parking lot in Folsom on Thursday, Jan. 22, an accident that tragically killed a pedestrian.

The crash happened just before 3 p.m. in the area of Folsom Blvd. and Iron Point Road at the Iron Point Light Rail station.

According to Folsom Police Commander Andrew Bates, the most current information is the vehicle veered off the roadway for unknown reasons, crashed into the light rail parking lot and struck a pedestrian and parked car before coming to rest on the light rail tracks.

The pedestrian was pronounced dead at the scene, according to Folsom PD Lt. Lou Wright, and the driver of the Tesla sustained injuries and was taken to a hospital.

SacRT reported the vehicle struck the ramp at the station and flipped over onto the tracks. The incident blocked the tracks between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom stations, which prompted a temporary halt of service.

Investigators were on scene trying to piece together what caused the crash and SacRT crews inspected the tracks to ensure there was no damage before service was resumed in the evening.

The crash created quite a spectacle, with various media outlets on scene taking pictures and video and onlookers also taking pictures.

title: Mystery as dad killed in train horror then called his family 35 times - Irish Mirror
np_html:
Mystery as dad killed in train horror then called his family 35 times

Charles Peck's mobile made 35 calls to loved ones for 11 hours after he was killed in the 2008 Chatsworth Metrolink disaster in California

View 3 Images The train failed to stop at a red signal (Image: AFP/Getty Images)

In a heart-wrenching and painful night for his family, a father-of-three's phone kept trying to reach his loved ones after his tragic death in a railway crash.

‌



Charles E Peck was one of the victims in the devastating San Fernando Valley Metrolink accident, now known as the Chatsworth crash.

‌



Peck, who was newly engaged to Andrea Katz and had three children from a previous marriage, was 49 at the time of the accident.

‌



On 12 September 2008 at 4:22pm, the commuter train he was on, carrying 225 passengers, collided with a freight train at a combined speed of 83 mph, according to Snopes.

The crash resulted in 135 people being injured, 87 of whom were rushed to hospital, with 46 in critical condition. Tragically, 25 people lost their lives, reports the Mirror US.

View 3 Images Charles Peck died on impact (Image: findagrave.com)

‌



Peck, who worked as a customer service agent for Delta Air Lines at Salt Lake City International Airport, died instantly. However, eerily, his mobile phone told a different story.

The 49-year-old had travelled to Los Angeles for a job interview at Van Nuys Airport - he was seeking employment in California so he could marry his Westlake Village fiancé.

Shockingly, Katz heard about the crash on the radio while she was en route to pick up Peck from the station. She was accompanied by his parents and siblings.

‌



In a horrifying twist, his loved ones began receiving phone calls from Peck's number. For 11 hours, they were flooded with distressing calls from his phone, reaching out to his son, brother, stepmother, sister, and fiancé.

A chilling total of 35 calls were made from the phone throughout the night - while his family were still unsure if he was dead or alive. The phone calls gave the grieving loved ones hope that he was still alive and simply trapped.

View 3 Images The accident was the deadliest in Metrolink history (Image: AFP)

‌



Upon answering the ghostly calls, all they heard was static and when they called back, the calls went straight to voicemail.

Eventually, Peck's body was recovered from the wreckage 12 hours after the accident.

The flurry of calls prompted search crews to trace the whereabouts of the phone through its signal and to once again sift through what was left of the first train, the location the calls were coming from.

‌



The searchers finally found Peck's body about an hour after the calls from his mobile phone stopped.

Eerily, it was discovered Peck died on impact - and his phone worked beyond his death to reach out to those who he loved most.

Ultimately these calls also meant his body was discovered, however his phone was never found.

Article continues below

A preliminary investigation into the deadliest accident in Metrolink's history found that the engineer operating the commuter train had failed to recognise a red signal.

This meant the train entered a single track with the Union Pacific freight train that was given the go ahead.

Charles Peck died on impact

In a heartbreaking and confusing hour a father-of-three's continued attempting to contact his loved ones following his tragic death in a rail disaster.

Charles E Peck was amongst the victims in the catastrophic San Fernando Valley Metrolink incident which became known as the Chatsworth crash. Article continues below ADVERTISEMENT

Peck was recently engaged to Andrea Katz and the 49-year-old had three children from a previous marriage.

On 12 September 2008 at 4:22pm the passenger train carrying 225 people collided at a combined speed of 83 mph with a freight train operated by a crew of three, according to Snopes.

Tragically, there were 135 people injured, 87 of whom were taken to hospital, with 46 in critical condition. Devastatingly, 25 died, reports the Mirror US. Article continues below ADVERTISEMENT

The accident was the deadliest in Metrolink history

Charles E Peck was amongst the victims in the catastrophic San Fernando Valley Metrolink incident which became known as the Chatsworth crash.Peck was recently engaged to Andrea Katz and the 49-year-old had three children from a previous marriage.On 12 September 2008 at 4:22pm the passenger train carrying 225 people collided at a combined speed of 83 mph with a freight train operated by a crew of three, according to Snopes.Tragically, there were 135 people injured, 87 of whom were taken to hospital, with 46 in critical condition. Devastatingly, 25 died, reports the Mirror US.The accident was the deadliest in Metrolink history (Image: AFP)Peck, a customer service agent for Delta Air Lines at Salt Lake City International Airport died on impact. However, eerily, his mobile phone told a different story.The 49-year-old had travelled to Los Angeles for a job interview at Van Nuys Airport - he was seeking new employment in California so he could marry his Westlake Village fiancée.Horrifically, Katz heard about the crash on the radio while she was travelling to collect Peck from the station. She was accompanied by his parents and siblings.Distressingly, his loved ones began receiving phone calls from Peck. For 11 hours they were bombarded with agonising calls from his phone, ringing his son, his brother, his stepmother, his sister, and his fiancée.A chilling total of 35 calls from the phone were made throughout the night - whilst his family remained uncertain whether he was dead or alive. The phone calls gave his distraught loved ones hope that he was still alive and simply trapped.The train failed to stop at a red signal (Image: AFP/Getty Images)Upon answering the mysterious calls, all they heard was static, and when they tried to ring back, the calls went straight to voicemail.Eventually, Peck's body was recovered from the wreckage 12 hours after the crash.The flurry of calls prompted search crews to trace the whereabouts of the phone through its signal and to once again comb through what remained of the first train, the location from which the calls were originating.The searchers finally discovered Peck's body about an hour after the calls from his mobile phone ceased.Hauntingly, it was discovered Peck died on impact - and his phone continued working beyond his death to reach out to those he loved most.Ultimately, these calls also ensured his body was found, however his phone was never recovered.A preliminary investigation into the deadliest accident in Metrolink's history found that the engineer operating the commuter train had failed to recognise a red signal.This meant the train entered a single track with the Union Pacific freight train that had been given the go ahead.
gs_html:
Charles E Peck was amongst the victims in the catastrophic San Fernando Valley Metrolink incident which became known as the Chatsworth crash.

On 12 September 2008 at 4:22pm the passenger train carrying 225 people collided at a combined speed of 83 mph with a freight train operated by a crew of three, according to Snopes.

Tragically, there were 135 people injured, 87 of whom were taken to hospital, with 46 in critical condition. Devastatingly, 25 died, reports the Mirror US.

The 49-year-old had travelled to Los Angeles for a job interview at Van Nuys Airport - he was seeking new employment in California so he could marry his Westlake Village fiancée.

Horrifically, Katz heard about the crash on the radio while she was travelling to collect Peck from the station. She was accompanied by his parents and siblings.

Distressingly, his loved ones began receiving phone calls from Peck. For 11 hours they were bombarded with agonising calls from his phone, ringing his son, his brother, his stepmother, his sister, and his fiancée.

A chilling total of 35 calls from the phone were made throughout the night - whilst his family remained uncertain whether he was dead or alive. The phone calls gave his distraught loved ones hope that he was still alive and simply trapped.

Upon answering the mysterious calls, all they heard was static, and when they tried to ring back, the calls went straight to voicemail.

The flurry of calls prompted search crews to trace the whereabouts of the phone through its signal and to once again comb through what remained of the first train, the location from which the calls were originating.

Hauntingly, it was discovered Peck died on impact - and his phone continued working beyond his death to reach out to those he loved most.

January 25, 2026 | Ontario, CA
A 43-year-old pedestrian lost his life in a tragic train accident near Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive, as detailed in a press release from the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.
Jamaal Lionel Scott, 43, died at the scene after a train struck him near Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive in Ontario.
What Happened in the Crash?
Jamaal Lionel Scott was struck by a train at around 10:49 a.m. on Jan. 25. He was pronounced dead at the location by responding officials. The Ontario Police Department has launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the incident.
- Victim: Jamaal Lionel Scott, 43 years old
- Location: Intersection of Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive, Ontario, CA
- Time: Approximately 10:49 a.m.
- Date: Jan. 25
- Outcome: Fatal injury at the scene
- Investigating Agency: Ontario Police Department
Why Do Train-Pedestrian Accidents Occur?
Train-related collisions can stem from various factors, such as errors by train operators, track defects, mechanical issues, signaling mistakes, or unsafe pedestrian areas. Authorities will assess whether the crossing was properly secured during their review.
According to the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), roughly 1,000 individuals lose their lives annually in train accidents across the U.S.

Legal Insights
In cases such as this, conducting an independent review promptly is crucial to gather vital evidence for affected families. National legal analyst Candice Bond, managing partner of Bond Legal, emphasized the importance of such steps.
“A skilled attorney can protect a grieving family from powerful train companies, which often send their investigators to crash sites and possess a variety of resources they can utilize to defend a negligent party,” said Bond.
- Preserve evidence through professional analysis to counter corporate investigations.
- Families may pursue claims for loss of companionship, emotional distress, and other damages.
- Legal support ensures rights are safeguarded amid complex investigations.
Stefano Formica, of counsel with Bond Legal, highlighted the emotional toll of such tragedies.
“The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Formica. “We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”
Pending investigation outcomes, the family of Jamaal Scott could be eligible for a wrongful death claim to address the profound effects of the loss.

np_html:
News Breaking News Jose Calderon killed in pedestrian-train crash, authorities say

SAN BERNARDINO COUNTY

The content of this page is covered by and subject to our legal disclaimer

Struck by Union Pacific train on South Cucamonga Avenue

ONTARIO, CA, (February 04, 2026) - A 44-year-old man was tragically killed in a pedestrian-train accident Wednesday morning in Ontario.

Jose Calderon died after being struck by a Union Pacific train in the 200 block of South Cucamonga Avenue in San Bernardino County. Incident Location

According to authorities, Ontario resident Jose Calderon was struck by a Union Pacific train at about 8:48 a.m. in the 200 block of South Cucamonga Avenue.

Calderon was pronounced deceased at the scene.

No additional details have been released.

FATAL PEDESTRIAN-TRAIN ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION Train accidents such as this can occur for several reasons, including train personnel error, train track failure, a mechanical error or malfunction, a signalman error, and reckless actions. According to the National Transportation Safety Bureau (NTSB), approximately 1,000 people are killed in train-related accidents each year. During the probe, investigators will also examine if the crash site was made safe for the pedestrian crossing. Candice Bond, an experienced train accident attorney, said that in cases such as this that it is imperative to have an independent investigation conducted by a seasoned lawyer as soon as possible to preserve evidence for a victim's family. “A skilled attorney can protect a grieving family from powerful train companies, which often send their investigators to crash sites and possess a variety of resources they can utilize to defend a negligent party,” said Bond, Managing Partner of Bond Legal and national analyst for The Legal Advocate.

WRONGFUL DEATH CLAIM Pending results of the investigation, family members of Jose Calderon may be entitled to a wrongful death claim. Family members of wrongful death victims may seek damages for loss of love and companionship, pain, suffering and emotional distress following a catastrophic accident such as this incident. “The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal. “We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”

(This report is based on verified data - learn more on our About Us page.)

ONTARIO, CA, (February 04, 2026) - A 44-year-old man was tragically killed in a pedestrian-train accident Wednesday morning in Ontario.

According to authorities, Ontario resident Jose Calderon was struck by a Union Pacific train at about 8:48 a.m. in the 200 block of South Cucamonga Avenue.

Calderon was pronounced deceased at the scene.

No additional details have been released.

Train accidents such as this can occur for several reasons, including train personnel error, train track failure, a mechanical error or malfunction, a signalman error, and reckless actions. According to the National Transportation Safety Bureau (NTSB), approximately 1,000 people are killed in train-related accidents each year. During the probe, investigators will also examine if the crash site was made safe for the pedestrian crossing. np_html:
News Breaking News Zukhra Kurbanova killed in Glendale Metrolink train crash, police say

LOS ANGELES COUNTY

The content of this page is covered by and subject to our legal disclaimer

Two people, including a bystander, were transported to a hospital

GLENDALE, CA, (February 04, 2026) - The Glendale Police Department said a 35-year-old woman was killed in a crash with a downtown Los Angeles-bound Metrolink train along Brazil Street on Wednesday morning.

Zukhra Kurbanova, 35, was killed Wednesday morning when her vehicle was struck by a downtown Los Angeles-bound Metrolink train at a crossing in Glendale.

She was identified by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner as Zukhra Kurbanova.

The crash occurred just west of the intersection of San Fernando Road and Broadway.

Kurbanova was driving a vehicle northbound on West San Fernando when she attempted to make a right turn onto Broadway around 9 a.m. and was struck by a Metrolink train traveling on the tracks. Tragically, she died at the scene from her injuries. The train was carrying roughly 150 passengers, three of whom were injured. One person was transported to a hospital. A bystander struck by debris from the crash was also hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries.

Two trains, each on the Antelope Valley and San Bernardino lines, were canceled after the collision.

This is an ongoing investigation.

CRASH INVESTIGATION NEEDED Train accidents such as this can occur for several reasons, including train personnel error, train track failure, a mechanical error or malfunction, a signalman error, and reckless actions. Each year, train-related crashes claim hundreds of lives across the United States. Many of these fatalities result from poorly marked crossings, malfunctioning signals and inadequate fencing. Railroad deaths totaled 954 in 2024, a 1% decrease from the 2023 revised total of 967, the National Safety Council said in a report. During the probe, investigators will also examine if the crash site was made safe for the crossing. Candice Bond, who specializes in train-related crashes, said that in cases such as this, it is imperative to have an independent investigation conducted by a seasoned lawyer as soon as possible to preserve evidence for a victim's family. “A skilled attorney can protect a grieving family from powerful train companies, which often send their investigators to crash sites and possess a variety of resources they can utilize to defend a negligent party,” said Bond, Managing Partner of Bond Legal.

WRONGFUL DEATH CLAIM Pending the investigation, the family members of Zukhra Kurbanova may be entitled to a wrongful death claim. Family members of wrongful death victims may seek damages for loss of companionship, pain, suffering, and emotional distress following a catastrophic accident such as this incident. “The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal. “We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”

(This report is based on verified data - learn more on our About Us page.)

title: Pedestrian killed in crash that impacted SacRT service in Folsom - KCRA
np_url:
A deadly crash impacted light rail service in Folsom on Thursday, according to the police department and Sacramento Regional Transit.The crash happened just before 3 p.m. near the Iron Point Station.SacRT said a vehicle struck the ramp at the station and overturned onto the tracks. The agency said the crash was blocking the tracks between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom stations, though SacRT was not involved in the collision. Folsom police said a pedestrian was killed in the crash, and one other person was taken to a hospital. Once the crash was cleared, SacRT said its crews would inspect the tracks for damage before service resumed. A bus bridge was in place along the impacted route.SacRT said regular service resumed around 8 p.m.Footage from the crash scene showed a sedan sitting on the tracks at an angle, with the rear of the vehicle resting on a handrail, and the front end on the tracks. LiveCopter 3 footage also showed damage in the station parking lot, indicating the vehicle traveled through there before violently crashing. See more coverage of top California stories here | Download our app | Subscribe to our morning newsletter | Find us on YouTube here and subscribe to our channel

Once the crash was cleared, SacRT said its crews would inspect the tracks for damage before service resumed. A bus bridge was in place along the impacted route.

title: Pedestrian dead after vehicle crash at Folsom light rail station - ABC10
np_url:
A fatal vehicle crash involving a pedestrian on a Folsom light rail platform has disrupted service.

Example video title will go here for this video

Next up in 5

Example video title will go here for this video

Next up in 5

To stream ABC10 News on your phone, you need the ABC10 News app.

FOLSOM, Calif. — A pedestrian is dead, and a driver was taken to the hospital after a crash Thursday afternoon at a Folsom light rail station, officials said.

The vehicle collided with the pedestrian around 2:50 p.m., according to the Folsom Police Department. The crash happened at the Iron Point Station, per Sacramento Regional Transit (SacRT).

The Folsom Fire Department said the vehicle hit a light rail platform and flipped over onto the tracks.

What led up to the crash is unknown.

Light rail service has been shut down in the affected area, officials said.

There is a bus bridge between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom light rail stations due to the blocked tracks, according to SacRT.

What led up to the crash is unknown.
Light rail service has been shut down in the affected area, officials said.
There is a bus bridge between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom light rail stations due to the blocked tracks, according to SacRT.

FOLSOM, Calif. — A pedestrian is dead, and a driver was taken to the hospital after a crash Thursday afternoon at a Folsom light rail station, officials said.

The vehicle collided with the pedestrian around 2:50 p.m., according to the Folsom Police Department. The crash happened at the Iron Point Station, per Sacramento Regional Transit (SacRT).

The Folsom Fire Department said the vehicle hit a light rail platform and flipped over onto the tracks.

What led up to the crash is unknown.

Light rail service has been shut down in the affected area, officials said.

There is a bus bridge between the Sunrise and Historic Folsom light rail stations due to the blocked tracks, according to SacRT.

‘Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information’ Notice
Like many content publishers, we provide online advertising services that use cookies and similar technologies to collect information about your device and online activity on our sites, apps and other online services. These services use this information to try to tailor the ads you see online to your interests. These are called interest-based ads. For more information about our collection, use and disclosure of your personal information when you visit our sites and apps, see our Privacy Policy.
Under certain state laws, including, but not limited to, the California Consumer Privacy Act, California Privacy Rights Act, and the Virginia Consumer Data Protection Act (collectively, “State Privacy Laws”), this collection and use of our users’ information for interest-based advertising purposes may constitute a “sale” of personal information to other parties. Certain State Privacy Laws require that we give you the ability to opt out of the sale or sharing of your personal information or data in connection with these targeting advertising activities. Although State Privacy Laws only extend their protections to residents of their particular states, we respect consumer choice when it comes to privacy rights. Accordingly, we offer all of our users – regardless of whether you are a resident of a state that has adopted a State Privacy Law – the right to opt out of this type of sale or sharing of your personal information. You can exercise this opt-out right by using the toggle switch below.
Opting out will not disable cookies or other technologies that facilitate the proper functioning of our website or collect data for purposes that do not involve targeted advertising. Opting out will not mean that you will stop seeing interest-based ads or other ads online. Specifically, opting out will not prevent you from seeing interest-based ads based on information that, for purposes of State Privacy Laws, was not sold or shared by us, was sold before you opted out, or was sold by third parties outside of our control. You can learn more about interest-based ads and additional opt-out choices here.
In addition, if you are a California resident and have enabled the Global Privacy Control (GPC) signal on a supported web browser, we will treat this as a request to opt-out of the sale or sharing of your personal information for targeted advertising purposes. For more information about what the GPC is and how to enable it, please visit globalprivacycontrol.org. More information

Targeting Cookies
These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. They do not store directly personal information, but are based on uniquely identifying your browser and internet device. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
Performance Cookies
These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site. All information these cookies collect is aggregated and therefore anonymous. If you do not allow these cookies we will not know when you have visited our site, and will not be able to monitor its performance.

title: Train accident in Spain leaves four people injured - The Jerusalem Post
np_html:
A commuter train collided with a crane in southeastern Spain on Thursday, emergency services said, in the country's fourth rail crash in less than a week.

Several people suffered minor injuries in the crash near the port city of Cartagena in the Murcia region, authorities added.

"The train hasn't been overturned or derailed," a spokesperson for Murcia's emergency services said. The first calls about the crash came in just after noon, they added.

Spain suffers several train accidents nationwide

Spain is still reeling from Sunday's high-speed train collision in the southern Andalusia region that killed at least 43 people.

Two days after that, a commuter train derailed after a containment wall fell on the track due to heavy rain near the city of Barcelona, killing the driver and seriously injuring four passengers.

Police and firefighters inspect the scene of a commuter train derailment, after a containment wall fell on the track due to heavy rain, killing the driver and injuring several people, in Gelida, near Barcelona, Spain, January 21, 2026. (credit: REUTERS/ALBERT GEA)

The main train drivers' union called a nationwide strike over safety standards after a second collision in the northeastern Catalonia region on Tuesday.

On Thursday, Spanish rail operator Adif said traffic on the line in Murcia was disrupted by what it described as "the intrusion into the infrastructure gauge by a crane not belonging to the railway operation." Its message on X did not go into more detail.

A later posting said services had resumed on the line.

title: What safety reforms reps want passed on East Palestine crash anniversary - Beaver County Times
np_url:
Feb. 3, 2026 Updated Feb. 4, 2026, 12:32 p.m. ET

Legislators are urging Congress to pass the Railway Safety Act on the third anniversary of the Norfolk Southern train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio.

The bill has received bipartisan support but has not moved forward to a vote in either the U.S. House or Senate.

The Railway Safety Act would increase safety regulations, require two-person crews, and improve communication with communities and first responders.

Railroad worker unions and labor organizations are advocating for the legislation, citing an increase in derailments and hazardous material releases since 2016.

Rep. Chris Deluzio and several other legislators are urging their colleagues in the U.S. House of Representatives and the Senate to finally pass legislation for stronger train safety regulations on the third anniversary of the Norfolk Southern train derailment disaster that has affected communities around East Palestine, Ohio, and the Darlington Township area of Beaver County.

Deluzio appeared with Rep. Mike Rulli of Ohio, Rep. John Garamendi of California, Rep. Dina Titus of Nevada, Rep. Mike Lawler of New York, representatives of associations for railroad workers, firefighters and labor unions and others at a Feb. 3 press conference in Washington, calling for Congress to resume efforts to pass the Railway Safety Act of 2025.

Communities helping each other: Patrick O'Shea: On darkest night, East Palestine people shone the brightest

The Railway Safety Act has received broad support from lawmakers in both the U.S. House and the Senate, Deluzio said in a Feb. 2 interview with The Beaver County Times.

He said that Vice President JD Vance, as a U.S. Senator from Ohio, sponsored the bill in the Senate in 2023 with Sen. John Fetterman and former Sens. Bob Casey of Pennsylvania and Sherrod Brown of Ohio. President Donald Trump also endorsed the Railway Safety Act as a presidential candidate, Deluzio said.

But three years after the derailment, he said, this legislation has not moved beyond those respective chambers, even as other communities across the country have been affected by train derailments involving the release of hazardous chemicals.

"A lot of people, whether in East Palestine or beside the border in Pennsylvania, they're still worried, they still have concerns about their health. I think everyone expects our government to change the rules to make trains operate more safely, so I'm in that fight for as long as it takes," Deluzio said.

Sen. John Fetterman also released a public statement on Feb. 3 to mark the derailment anniversary and urged his fellow senators to pass the Railway Safety Act, calling the bill "commonsense legislation" and adding that after three years, "Congress still hasn't done right by these communities."

What is the Railway Safety Act?

The Railway Safety Act would improve railway safety by broadening the list of hazardous materials where additional safety protections are required when shipped by rail, and require that railroads notify state emergency response officials in advance when, where and what kinds of hazardous materials are being transported by rail through their communities.

The act would also require a minimum of two crew members on a freight train, increase and enforce railcar inspections and expand the use of wayside defect detectors along railroads to alert railroad workers to potential defects and equipment failures. The National Transportation Safety Board determined in June 2024 that a wheel bearing on a railcar failed and overheated, causing the train derailment in East Palestine.

The legislation would also increase maximum fines on rail carriers for violating safety regulations, which now are more of "a slap on the wrist," Deluzio said.

"(T)he folks who live around the tracks, they can't be treated like collateral damage (for) railroad profits. So I think the safety measures are about making sure our communities have more confidence that when trains are coming through carrying something dangerous, they’re operating more safely, that you have notification to first responders about what's on the trains coming through."

Under Pressure Act: Congress introduces another bill to prevent train derailment disasters

'It's about partnership'

Matt Pacifico, the mayor of Altoona in Blair County, spoke at the press conference about a 17-car derailment that occurred in 2014 in his city and how he found out about the derailment, not from the railroad but from a news reporter calling for his comment on the accident.

"That moment made something very clear; when it comes to rail safety, communication between railroads and the communities they pass through is not where it needs to be," he said.

"Local leaders and first responders should never be the last to know when something happens on the tracks that run through the center of their cities. Effective rail safety depends not only on what happens on the rails, but on how well railroads communicate with the people responsible for protecting the public where those rails run.

"This isn't about placing blame; it's about partnership. It's about railroads being good neighbors in the communities across the country by keeping us informed and involved, because when communication improves, rail safety improves for everyone."

Unions offer support for Railway Safety Act

Rail workers have been involved in formulating the regulations in the Railway Safety Act and are advocating for these reforms, according to Michael Baldwin, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen and chair of the Rail Labor Division of the Transportation Trades Department of the AFL-CIO.

"Let's say this plainly, because the truth matters: This (the East Palestine derailment) was not a fluke, this was not bad luck. It was the foreseeable result of a system that has been allowed, even encouraged, to put profits ahead of safety," Baldwin said at the Feb. 3 press conference in Washington.

"For years, rail workers have been sounding the alarm. We warned of longer trains with fewer crew members, we warned of rushed inspections, we warned about outdated braking systems, we warned about relentless pressure to move faster, haul more and do it all with less.

"Today, we are calling on Congress to act and pass the Railway Safety Act. We weren't asking for special treatment; we were asking for basic safety, for ourselves and for the communities we pass through every single day.

"When we demand change, we make sure what happened here never happens again."

Greg Regan, president of the Transportation Trades Department of the AFL-CIO, said during the press conference that the derailment rate on mainline tracks has increased 25% over the last 10 years, and hazardous materials releases have increased 23% during that same period.

"That is an unacceptable level of risk, and one that we should be demanding better of. Congress should be demanding it, unions should be demanding it," Regan said.

The TTD represents workers in 40 unions nationwide, including all freight and passenger rail transportation workers.

"Not a single person in this room is advocating for hurting the railroads; we actually want to see the railroads grow. We think they're an important economic driver of this country, we think they're the best way to move a lot of these goods across the country in a way that is most efficient, best for communities, best for economic development," Regan said.

"But when you look at where safety is going on class one railroads, it would be alarming in any other industry. There would be a reckoning if we had the types of numbers we're talking about in class 1 railroads and freight rail in aviation, or trucking (industry). The labor movement is ready to work with you all, to make sure that we can achieve a rail system that we can all be proud of.

"I do not want to be back here next year, or at the five-year anniversary, the 10-year anniversary, or heaven forbid, when there's another tragedy, one that shocks another community, or even worse, when lives are lost because of that tragedy. We cannot accept the status quo as good enough."

"When we demand change, we make sure what happened here never happens again."
Greg Regan, president of the Transportation Trades Department of the AFL-CIO, said during the press conference that the derailment rate on mainline tracks has increased 25% over the last 10 years, and hazardous materials releases have increased 23% during that same period.
"That is an unacceptable level of risk, and one that we should be demanding better of. Congress should be demanding it, unions should be demanding it," Regan said.
The TTD represents workers in 40 unions nationwide, including all freight and passenger rail transportation workers.
"Not a single person in this room is advocating for hurting the railroads; we actually want to see the railroads grow. We think they're an important economic driver of this country, we think they're the best way to move a lot of these goods across the country in a way that is most efficient, best for communities, best for economic development," Regan said.
"But when you look at where safety is going on class one railroads, it would be alarming in any other industry. There would be a reckoning if we had the types of numbers we're talking about in class 1 railroads and freight rail in aviation, or trucking (industry). The labor movement is ready to work with you all, to make sure that we can achieve a rail system that we can all be proud of.
"I do not want to be back here next year, or at the five-year anniversary, the 10-year anniversary, or heaven forbid, when there's another tragedy, one that shocks another community, or even worse, when lives are lost because of that tragedy. We cannot accept the status quo as good enough."

gs_html:
Legislators are urging Congress to pass the Railway Safety Act on the third anniversary of the Norfolk Southern train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio.
• The bill has received bipartisan support but has not moved forward to a vote in either the U.S. House or Senate.
• The Railway Safety Act would increase safety regulations, require two-person crews, and improve communication with communities and first responders.
• Railroad worker unions and labor organizations are advocating for the legislation, citing an increase in derailments and hazardous material releases since 2016.

Rep. Chris Deluzio and several other legislators are urging their colleagues in the U.S. House of Representatives and the Senate to finally pass legislation for stronger train safety regulations on the third anniversary of the Norfolk Southern train derailment disaster that has affected communities around East Palestine, Ohio, and the Darlington Township area of Beaver County.

Deluzio appeared with Rep. Mike Rulli of Ohio, Rep. John Garamendi of California, Rep. Dina Titus of Nevada, Rep. Mike Lawler of New York, representatives of associations for railroad workers, firefighters and labor unions and others at a Feb. 3 press conference in Washington, calling for Congress to resume efforts to pass the Railway Safety Act of 2025.

The Railway Safety Act has received broad support from lawmakers in both the U.S. House and the Senate, Deluzio said in a Feb. 2 interview with The Beaver County Times.

He said that Vice President JD Vance, as a U.S. Senator from Ohio, sponsored the bill in the Senate in 2023 with Sen. John Fetterman and former Sens. Bob Casey of Pennsylvania and Sherrod Brown of Ohio. President Donald Trump also endorsed the Railway Safety Act as a presidential candidate, Deluzio said.

But three years after the derailment, he said, this legislation has not moved beyond those respective chambers, even as other communities across the country have been affected by train derailments involving the release of hazardous chemicals.

"A lot of people, whether in East Palestine or beside the border in Pennsylvania, they're still worried, they still have concerns about their health. I think everyone expects our government to change the rules to make trains operate more safely, so I'm in that fight for as long as it takes," Deluzio said.

Sen. John Fetterman also released a public statement on Feb. 3 to mark the derailment anniversary and urged his fellow senators to pass the Railway Safety Act, calling the bill "commonsense legislation" and adding that after three years, "Congress still hasn't done right by these communities."

What is the Railway Safety Act?

The Railway Safety Act would improve railway safety by broadening the list of hazardous materials where additional safety protections are required when shipped by rail, and require that railroads notify state emergency response officials in advance when, where and what kinds of hazardous materials are being transported by rail through their communities.

The act would also require a minimum of two crew members on a freight train, increase and enforce railcar inspections and expand the use of wayside defect detectors along railroads to alert railroad workers to potential defects and equipment failures. The National Transportation Safety Board determined in June 2024 that a wheel bearing on a railcar failed and overheated, causing the train derailment in East Palestine.

The legislation would also increase maximum fines on rail carriers for violating safety regulations, which now are more of "a slap on the wrist," Deluzio said.

"(T)he folks who live around the tracks, they can't be treated like collateral damage (for) railroad profits. So I think the safety measures are about making sure our communities have more confidence that when trains are coming through carrying something dangerous, they’re operating more safely, that you have notification to first responders about what's on the trains coming through."

Matt Pacifico, the mayor of Altoona in Blair County, spoke at the press conference about a 17-car derailment that occurred in 2014 in his city and how he found out about the derailment, not from the railroad but from a news reporter calling for his comment on the accident.

"That moment made something very clear; when it comes to rail safety, communication between railroads and the communities they pass through is not where it needs to be," he said.

"Local leaders and first responders should never be the last to know when something happens on the tracks that run through the center of their cities. Effective rail safety depends not only on what happens on the rails, but on how well railroads communicate with the people responsible for protecting the public where those rails run.

"This isn't about placing blame; it's about partnership. It's about railroads being good neighbors in the communities across the country by keeping us informed and involved, because when communication improves, rail safety improves for everyone."

Rail workers have been involved in formulating the regulations in the Railway Safety Act and are advocating for these reforms, according to Michael Baldwin, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen and chair of the Rail Labor Division of the Transportation Trades Department of the AFL-CIO.

"Let's say this plainly, because the truth matters: This (the East Palestine derailment) was not a fluke, this was not bad luck. It was the foreseeable result of a system that has been allowed, even encouraged, to put profits ahead of safety," Baldwin said at the Feb. 3 press conference in Washington.

"For years, rail workers have been sounding the alarm. We warned of longer trains with fewer crew members, we warned of rushed inspections, we warned about outdated braking systems, we warned about relentless pressure to move faster, haul more and do it all with less.

"Today, we are calling on Congress to act and pass the Railway Safety Act. We weren't asking for special treatment; we were asking for basic safety, for ourselves and for the communities we pass through every single day.

"When we demand change, we make sure what happened here never happens again."

Greg Regan, president of the Transportation Trades Department of the AFL-CIO, said during the press conference that the derailment rate on mainline tracks has increased 25% over the last 10 years, and hazardous materials releases have increased 23% during that same period.

"That is an unacceptable level of risk, and one that we should be demanding better of. Congress should be demanding it, unions should be demanding it," Regan said.

The TTD represents workers in 40 unions nationwide, including all freight and passenger rail transportation workers.

"Not a single person in this room is advocating for hurting the railroads; we actually want to see the railroads grow. We think they're an important economic driver of this country, we think they're the best way to move a lot of these goods across the country in a way that is most efficient, best for communities, best for economic development," Regan said.

"But when you look at where safety is going on class one railroads, it would be alarming in any other industry. There would be a reckoning if we had the types of numbers we're talking about in class 1 railroads and freight rail in aviation, or trucking (industry). The labor movement is ready to work with you all, to make sure that we can achieve a rail system that we can all be proud of.

"I do not want to be back here next year, or at the five-year anniversary, the 10-year anniversary, or heaven forbid, when there's another tragedy, one that shocks another community, or even worse, when lives are lost because of that tragedy. We cannot accept the status quo as good enough."

title: NJ Transit derailment traced to blind‑curve collision, officials say - NJ.com
np_url:
Federal investigators have released preliminary findings on the collision last month between two NJ Transit trains in Montclair, which derailed two trains and left crew members injured.

On Dec. 19, 2025, an eastbound train struck a stopped train on a sharp curve west of Bay Street, according to a preliminary report released Friday by the National Transportation Safety Board.

The standing train did not come into view of the striking train until it was about 126 feet away.

The train that struck the stopped train was traveling about 17 mph and operating under a restricted‑speed signal that required it to move slowly enough to stop within sight, the NTSB said.

Investigators said they will now turn their attention to whether Positive Train Control functioned as intended while the train was operating under restricted-speed rules.

The preliminary report did not note any findings about the system, which was installed on all NJ Transit trains in 2018 to satisfy a federal requirement.

At the site of an NJ Transit train collision near Bay Street Station in Montclair, New Jersey on Friday Dec. 19, 2025. Ian Peters | For NJ Advance Media

“Determining what role—if any—PTC played or could have played in the collision remains part of the ongoing investigation. No conclusions have been reached at this time,” Keith Holloway, a NTSB spokesperson, said in response to emailed questions by NJ Advance Media. Typically, the agency completes crash investigations within one to two years.

Emergency crews responded to the scene after the trains collided last month.

Six crew members—three from each train—were hospitalized for non-life-threatening injuries. The 11 passengers on the struck train declined further medical treatment.

The crash caused about $180,000 in damage to the trains and tracks, the NTSB said. NJ Transit declined to comment when reached by NJ Advance Media.

At the site of an NJ Transit train collision near Bay Street Station in Montclair, New Jersey on Friday Dec. 19, 2025. Ian Peters | For NJ Advance Media

Before the collision, both trains had been traveling westbound on track 1.

NJ Transit rerouted them onto track 2 in the opposite direction—sending them eastbound—to avoid downed trees that were blocking the line after a storm earlier that evening, federal investigators said.

At the crash site, investigators examined the track, signals and equipment.

They also conducted sight‑distance observations using trains, reviewed event recorder data and image recorders from both trains. The NTSB also requested NJ Transit’s dispatcher radio and telephone recordings, and interviewed employees.

As the investigation continues, the NTSB said it will also review maintenance and inspection records and signal information.

title: Recovery of missing dog Boro brings hope after Spain’s train crashes - AP News
np_url:
Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google.

Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share

MADRID (AP) — After back-to-back fatal train crashes sent shock waves through Spain, some good news arrived on Thursday: Boro, the missing dog, was found.

Days earlier, Boro’s owner Ana García issued a desperate plea to help find him after the dog bolted Sunday in the aftermath of the high-speed train crash in southern Spain that killed at least 45 people. García, 26, and her pregnant sister were traveling with Boro on the train that derailed.

On Thursday, forest firefighters in southern Spain found the black-and-white pooch, and posted images that showed García with one of her legs in a brace embracing Boro. Sitting inside a car, she spoke to reporters.

“Many thanks to all of Spain and everyone who has got involved so much,” she said. “It gave me great hope and we’ve done it.”

The search for Boro appeared to provide Spaniards something to hope for amid the week’s tragedy, and ultimately something to celebrate.

A woman holds a sign reading in Spanish, “Missing Boro. Lost during the Adamuz accident. Any information is helpful,” about a dog that went missing during a train crash in Adamuz, southern Spain, Wednesday, Jan. 21, 2026. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez) A woman holds a sign reading in Spanish, “Missing Boro. Lost during the Adamuz accident. Any information is helpful,” about a dog that went missing during a train crash in Adamuz, southern Spain, Wednesday, Jan. 21, 2026. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook

Copy Link copied

Print

Email

X

LinkedIn

Bluesky

Flipboard

Pinterest

Reddit Read More

For days, people had rallied online to find him, amplifying García’s call by sharing video of an interview she had given to local media. Photos of Boro, a medium-sized black dog with white eyebrows, went viral alongside phone numbers for García and her family. Spanish television broadcasters and newspapers covered the search.

García, her sister and the dog had been traveling Sunday by high-speed train from Malaga, their hometown in southern Spain, to the capital Madrid, when the tail of their train car jumped the rails for reasons that remain unclear, and smashed into another train.

The collision killed dozens and injured more than 150 people. Rescue crews helped García and her sister out of the tilted train car. That’s when she briefly saw Boro before he ran. She spoke to the cameras with a blanket draped over her shoulders and a bandage on her cheek after Spain’s worst rail accident in more than a decade.

Guardia Civil officers collect evidence next to the wreckage of train cars involved in a collision in Adamuz, southern Spain, Tuesday, Jan. 20, 2026. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez) Guardia Civil officers collect evidence next to the wreckage of train cars involved in a collision in Adamuz, southern Spain, Tuesday, Jan. 20, 2026. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook

Copy Link copied

Print

Email

X

LinkedIn

Bluesky

Flipboard

Pinterest

Reddit Read More

“Please, if you can help, look for the animals,” a limping García told reporters at the time, choked up and holding back tears. “We were coming back from a family weekend with the little dog, who’s family, too.”

On Thursday, she had a bruise beneath her eye but, with Boro back by her side, also a smile plastered across her face.

“Now we have him and we have him for all our life,” García told reporters. “Now let’s go home, buddy.”

___

Associated Press journalist Teresa Medrano in Madrid contributed to this report.

On Thursday, she had a bruise beneath her eye but, with Boro back by her side, also a smile plastered across her face.“Now we have him and we have him for all our life,” García told reporters. “Now let’s go home, buddy.” ___Associated Press journalist Teresa Medrano in Madrid contributed to this report.
gs_url:
Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google.

Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share

MADRID (AP) — After back-to-back fatal train crashes sent shock waves through Spain, some good news arrived on Thursday: Boro, the missing dog, was found.

Days earlier, Boro’s owner Ana García issued a desperate plea to help find him after the dog bolted Sunday in the aftermath of the high-speed train crash in southern Spain that killed at least 45 people. García, 26, and her pregnant sister were traveling with Boro on the train that derailed.

On Thursday, forest firefighters in southern Spain found the black-and-white pooch, and posted images that showed García with one of her legs in a brace embracing Boro. Sitting inside a car, she spoke to reporters.

“Many thanks to all of Spain and everyone who has got involved so much,” she said. “It gave me great hope and we’ve done it.”

The search for Boro appeared to provide Spaniards something to hope for amid the week’s tragedy, and ultimately something to celebrate.

For days, people had rallied online to find him, amplifying García’s call by sharing video of an interview she had given to local media. Photos of Boro, a medium-sized black dog with white eyebrows, went viral alongside phone numbers for García and her family. Spanish television broadcasters and newspapers covered the search.

García, her sister and the dog had been traveling Sunday by high-speed train from Malaga, their hometown in southern Spain, to the capital Madrid, when the tail of their train car jumped the rails for reasons that remain unclear, and smashed into another train.

The collision killed dozens and injured more than 150 people. Rescue crews helped García and her sister out of the tilted train car. That’s when she briefly saw Boro before he ran. She spoke to the cameras with a blanket draped over her shoulders and a bandage on her cheek after Spain’s worst rail accident in more than a decade.

“Please, if you can help, look for the animals,” a limping García told reporters at the time, choked up and holding back tears. “We were coming back from a family weekend with the little dog, who’s family, too.”

On Thursday, she had a bruise beneath her eye but, with Boro back by her side, also a smile plastered across her face.

“Now we have him and we have him for all our life,” García told reporters. “Now let’s go home, buddy.”

Associated Press journalist Teresa Medrano in Madrid contributed to this report.

title: Pedestrian killed in train accident on West Martin Street, police say - kens5.com
tf_url:
SAN ANTONIO — A pedestrian was killed Saturday morning after being struck by a train on the west side near downtown, according to San Antonio police.
Officers were called to the 1200 block of West Martin Street around 10:28 a.m. for a major accident involving a train and a person on the tracks.
Police said it is still unclear how the pedestrian ended up on the train tracks. The person was pronounced dead at the scene.
The pedestrian has not been identified at this time.
The incident remains under investigation.

title: Pedestrian killed after hit by train while seated on the tracks, police say - kens5.com
np_url:
Police say a pedestrian was killed after being struck by a train near South St. Mary’s Street late Saturday night.

Example video title will go here for this video

Example video title will go here for this video

To stream KENS 5 on your phone, you need the KENS 5 app.

SAN ANTONIO — A pedestrian was killed late Saturday night after being struck by a train near South St. Mary’s Street, according to police.

Officers were called to the intersection of South St. Mary’s and Lone Star around 10:58 p.m. for a major accident involving a train and a person on the tracks.

Police said the pedestrian was reportedly seated on the tracks and did not move after the train’s horn sounded.

The person was pronounced dead at the scene. The pedestrian has not been identified at this time.

Union Pacific released this statement about the incident:

"Just before 11 p.m. local time Saturday, a person trespassing on the railroad tracks in the area of Groveton St. and Roosevelt Ave. in San Antonio, Texas, was struck by a train and died. The incident did not occur at a crossing. The train crew was not hurt, but witnessed the incident and is being offered support. No additional information is available about the trespasser."

‘Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information’ NoticeLike many content publishers, we provide online advertising services that use cookies and similar technologies to collect information about your device and online activity on our sites, apps and other online services. These services use this information to try to tailor the ads you see online to your interests. These are called interest-based ads. For more information about our collection, use and disclosure of your personal information when you visit our sites and apps, see our Privacy Policy.

Under certain state laws, including, but not limited to, the California Consumer Privacy Act, California Privacy Rights Act, and the Virginia Consumer Data Protection Act (collectively, “State Privacy Laws”), this collection and use of our users’ information for interest-based advertising purposes may constitute a “sale” of personal information to other parties.  Certain State Privacy Laws require that we give you the ability to opt out of the sale or sharing of your personal information or data in connection with these targeting advertising activities. Although State Privacy Laws only extend their protections to residents of their particular states, we respect consumer choice when it comes to privacy rights.  Accordingly, we offer all of our users – regardless of whether you are a resident of a state that has adopted a State Privacy Law – the right to opt out of this type of sale or sharing of your personal information.  You can exercise this opt-out right by using the toggle switch below.  


Opting out will not disable cookies or other technologies that facilitate the proper functioning of our website or collect data for purposes that do not involve targeted advertising. Opting out will not mean that you will stop seeing interest-based ads or other ads online. Specifically, opting out will not prevent you from seeing interest-based ads based on information that, for purposes of State Privacy Laws, was not sold or shared by us, was sold before you opted out, or was sold by third parties outside of our control. You can learn more about interest-based ads and additional opt-out choices here.

In addition, if you are a California resident and have enabled the Global Privacy Control (GPC) signal on a supported web browser, we will treat this as a request to opt-out of the sale or sharing of your personal information for targeted advertising purposes. For more information about what the GPC is and how to enable it, please visit globalprivacycontrol.org.
More information Manage Consent PreferencesAlways Active   Strictly Necessary CookiesThese cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information. Confirm My Choices

UPDATE: Cooper Flagg is OUT for All-Star Weekend, No Reason to Worry?

To stream KENS 5 on your phone, you need the KENS 5 app.

SAN ANTONIO — A pedestrian was killed late Saturday night after being struck by a train near South St. Mary’s Street, according to police.

Officers were called to the intersection of South St. Mary’s and Lone Star around 10:58 p.m. for a major accident involving a train and a person on the tracks.

Police said the pedestrian was reportedly seated on the tracks and did not move after the train’s horn sounded.

The person was pronounced dead at the scene. The pedestrian has not been identified at this time.

"Just before 11 p.m. local time Saturday, a person trespassing on the railroad tracks in the area of Groveton St. and Roosevelt Ave. in San Antonio, Texas, was struck by a train and died. The incident did not occur at a crossing. The train crew was not hurt, but witnessed the incident and is being offered support. No additional information is available about the trespasser."

title: Track fractured before Spanish train disaster, report finds - AOL.com
np_url:
Grooves were found on wheels of the Iryo train that had already passed over the track before the derailment [Spain's CIAF]

A fracture in a straight section of track "occurred prior to the passage" of a high-speed train that derailed, causing last Sunday's rail disaster in which 45 people died, an initial report has found.

A train run by private company Iryo derailed last Sunday and its rear carriages crossed on to the opposite track into the path of an oncoming train run by state-owned Renfe.

The CIAF rail investigation commission said not only did Iryo train's front carriages which stayed on the track have "notches" in their wheels, but three earlier trains that went over the track earlier did too.

A gap of almost 40cm (15in) in the track has become the focus of the investigation into the crash.

Sunday's deadly collision occurred at around 19:45 local time (18:45 GMT), about an hour after the Iryo train left Málaga for Madrid.

The train's last three carriages - carriages six to eight - derailed and collided with the Huelva-bound Renfe train. "Carriage six derailed due to a complete lack of continuity in the track," the preliminary report finds.

Most of those killed and injured were in the front carriages of the state-operated train.

The 40cm gap in the track was clearly visible the day after the disaster at Adamuz [Guardia Civil]

Earlier this week, Spanish Transport Minister Óscar Puente confirmed reports that grooves were found on the wheels of the Iryo train's carriages, which had passed over the track safely.

"These notches in the wheels and the deformation observed in the track are compatible with the fact that the track was cracked," the CIAF preliminary report said.

It added that three trains that had gone over the tracks at 17:21 on Sunday, 19:01 and then 19:09 had similar notches "with a compatible geometric pattern".

Similar grooves are found on carriages two, three and four of the Iryo train, the report says, but carriage five - the last that did not derail - had a groove on its outer edge, suggesting the rail was already tilting outwards before carriage six derailed.

The CIAF called its report a "working hypothesis", adding that it "must be corroborated by later detailed calculations and analysis".

The transport minister appeared before reporters again on Friday to say that it was too early to have definitive answers, but that if the cause of the crash was the fracture, then it occurred in the minutes and hours before the derailment and could not have been detected.

The Adamuz disaster is is the country's worst rail crash in more than a decade.

In 2013, Spain suffered its worst high-speed train derailment in Galicia, north-west Spain, which left 80 people dead and 140 others injured.

A fracture in a straight section of track "occurred prior to the passage" of a high-speed train that derailed, causing last Sunday's rail disaster in which 45 people died, an initial report has found.

A train run by private company Iryo derailed last Sunday and its rear carriages crossed on to the opposite track into the path of an oncoming train run by state-owned Renfe.

The CIAF rail investigation commission said not only did Iryo train's front carriages which stayed on the track have "notches" in their wheels, but three earlier trains that went over the track earlier did too.

A gap of almost 40cm (15in) in the track has become the focus of the investigation into the crash.

Sunday's deadly collision occurred at around 19:45 local time (18:45 GMT), about an hour after the Iryo train left Málaga for Madrid.

The train's last three carriages - carriages six to eight - derailed and collided with the Huelva-bound Renfe train. "Carriage six derailed due to a complete lack of continuity in the track," the preliminary report finds.

Most of those killed and injured were in the front carriages of the state-operated train.

Earlier this week, Spanish Transport Minister Óscar Puente confirmed reports that grooves were found on the wheels of the Iryo train's carriages, which had passed over the track safely.

"These notches in the wheels and the deformation observed in the track are compatible with the fact that the track was cracked," the CIAF preliminary report said.

It added that three trains that had gone over the tracks at 17:21 on Sunday, 19:01 and then 19:09 had similar notches "with a compatible geometric pattern".

Similar grooves are found on carriages two, three and four of the Iryo train, the report says, but carriage five - the last that did not derail - had a groove on its outer edge, suggesting the rail was already tilting outwards before carriage six derailed.

The CIAF called its report a "working hypothesis", adding that it "must be corroborated by later detailed calculations and analysis".

The transport minister appeared before reporters again on Friday to say that it was too early to have definitive answers, but that if the cause of the crash was the fracture, then it occurred in the minutes and hours before the derailment and could not have been detected.

The Adamuz disaster is is the country's worst rail crash in more than a decade.

In 2013, Spain suffered its worst high-speed train derailment in Galicia, north-west Spain, which left 80 people dead and 140 others injured.

title: Pedestrian struck and killed on Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu - CBS News
np_html: gs_html
tf_html:
Pedestrian struck and killed on Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu
Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu was temporarily closed on Monday night after a pedestrian was struck and killed.
It happened at around 7:30 p.m. in the 27280 block of PCH near Winding Way, just east of Kanan Dume, according to the California Highway Patrol.
The victim was pronounced dead at the scene by Los Angeles County Fire Department paramedics. He was identified by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner as 44-year-old Joshua Farmer on Tuesday. Authorities believe he was homeless.
Officers said that the driver of the car that hit the pedestrian stayed at the scene to cooperate with their investigation. They do not believe that driving under the influence or speed were factors in the collision.
The cause of the crash remains under investigation.
PCH was expected to be closed between East Winding Way and West Winding Way for several hours, police said.

title: Bihar train disaster | Railway Accident, Fatalities, India - Britannica
np_url:
Table of Contents Ask Anything

Bihar train disaster, train wreck that killed hundreds of people on June 6, 1981, when a passenger train derailed on a bridge and plunged into the Baghmati River in the state of Bihar, northern India.

The passenger train was moving from Mansi to Saharsa when seven of the train’s nine cars fell into the river. The explanation for the train’s derailment is not entirely known. Some reports stated that the train’s engineer sharply applied the brakes to avoid hitting a cow that had walked onto the tracks. Slippery conditions caused by torrential rains also were likely a factor. The chances for a successful rescue were remote, as the monsoon rains made the river conditions deadly; moreover, help was not immediately available near the disaster site. When rescuers finally did arrive, they searched the area for survivors for several days. At least 250 fatalities were confirmed; hundreds more passengers were never found.

natural disaster Homework Help Britannica AI Ask Anything Quick Summary

Table of Contents

Table of Contents Quick Summary Ask Anything

Top Questions What is a natural disaster?
